string.text: Standard equipment used by Clear Sky assault squads. This body armour is able to stop a pistol bullet, while also providing good protection from anomalous exposure. Includes a container capable of holding one artefact.
This body armour was once used for conducting search operations in areas of low anomalous activity. Comes with a built-in artefact containers.
The CS-3a body armour was once used as a standard by Clear Sky troopers. The CS-3a consists of a military bulletproof vest with a load bearing vest over it. Comes with a built-in artefact containers.
Once used as standard by Clear Sky assault squads. The armour is capable of stopping a pistol bullet, while the wearer is also well protected from anomalies. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

The SSP-99 chemical protection suit is specially designed for the Zone conditions, used by Ecologist and Stalkers who cooperate with them. The suit has an integrated air-filtering and air-conditioning system, it is also heat and electricity resistant and provides good protection from radiation and biological anomalies. It is resistant to chemically aggressive environments. It is not designed for combat, so it provides neither bullet, nor splinter protection. The suit has two artefact containers.

The SSP-99M chemical protection suit is specially designed for scientific expeditions into the Zone. The SSP-99M is a high quality modified SSP-99 suit. It provides increased body protection from bullets and splinters, as it was designed for guards working with scientific expeditions. The suit has two artefact containers.

This bodysuit is a combination of a bodysuit of twin-layered rubberized cloth with plexiglass lining and built-in body armour. Created specifically for members of the Ecologist faction, this suit is modelled after the popular Sunrise suit. Comes with built-in artefact containers.

This modern version of the Duty bodysuit is better suited for stalker recruits who are used to lightweight suits. Unlike the PSZ series, this suit provides good protection against anomalies while also being capable of stopping a pistol bullet. The suit cannot be modified with an artefact container, but may be upgraded with a combat support system instead.

This early model of the Duty bodysuit is the Spetsnaz PSZ-9 body armour modified for the Zone. The suit is capable of stopping a rifle bullet, however, this level of protection comes at the cost of its weight, bulkiness and virtually non-existent anomaly protection. The suit cannot be modified with an artefact container, but may be upgraded with a combat support system.

The Duty members decided using heavier materials to improve bullet resistance over others, this version of the exoskeleton though heavy makes one feel like a tank. The only downfall is the weak anomaly protection provided with the armour is very lacking and even the most basic of anomalies can take down this tank. Does not come with an artefact container.

A wonderful protective suit for the Zone. Stalkers appreciate it because it combines excellent anomaly-proof and bullet-proof qualities. It includes the PSZ-9d suit, a closed cycle breathing system and an integrated system of anomalous field suppression. It provides quality bullet and splinter protection. Does not come with an artefact container.

This stalker bodysuit with reinforced body armour made by Freedom craftsmen represents a good compromise between combat and anomaly protection. The built-in body armour comprises armour plating and ten Kevlar layers, capable of stopping a pistol bullet. The suit uses the relatively expensive Sovereign compound for anomaly protection. Comes with an artefact container.

This lightweight stalker bodysuit is made by Freedom craftsmen. The suit's fabric is treated with Horizon, a special solution developed by the faction by trial and error to increase resistance to anomalies. Like the Sunrise suit, the Wind of Freedom comes with built-in body armour and artefact container.

A modern Freedom model. It is more suitable to new stalker recruits, who are used to simpler suits. Unlike the PS3 series, this variation provides decent protection from anomalies and minimal protection from bullets. Comes with built-in artefact container.

An upgraded version of a regular exoskeleton. The use of lighter materials allowed the designers to reduce the suit's weight and with Freedom's usual trademark of high quality anomaly protection the only thing that suffers is its overall armour and impact. Comes with built-in artefact container.

Produced with the participation of partisans from the group "Freedom" for especially for research in the Zone. The closed system of breathing and special treatment materials provide excellent protection against harmful radiation and anomalous effects. However, a built-in body armour breaks even pistol bullets, so the suit is not suitable for active hostilities. Fully upgradeable and boasting built-in artefact container.

The leather jacket does not provide sufficient protection from the Zone's harsh conditions, since it's simply a leather anorak with blue trousers tucked into hiking boots. Typically, it's also worn with a backpack with extra straps across the chest. Leather offers little protection from gunfire or claws and it's absolutely useless against radiation or anomalies.

This DIY stalker bodysuit is a combination of a bodysuit of twin-layered rubberized cloth with plexiglass lining and built-in body armour. Despite the fact that the body armour is incapable of protecting the wearer from even pistol bullets, the suit enjoys great popularity due to its low cost and modification potential. Comes with built-in artefact container.

An experimental sample of a military exoskeleton. Was never mass-produced due to extraordinary cost and some design flaws. Despite this, it is in demand due to its ability to take on the weight of all carried equipment, and therefore small batches are made in underground facilities outside Ukraine. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

This suit, produced by one of Kiev's Defence Research Institutes, is a great alternative to home-made stalker suits. While its built-in body armour can only stop a pistol round, the anomaly and radiation protection system is second to none. Fully upgradeable and boasting built-in artefact container, this bodysuit is the equipment of choice for many experienced stalkers.

Outfit of choice for the Mercenary faction. It's design is based on the suit used by the special forces of the Western armies. Due to a special treatment of the fabric, the armour has a strengthened stability during the physical movement of its plates. Comes with built-in artefact containers.
An experimental sample of a military exoskeleton. Painted in mercenary colours, their demand is high between veteran mercs. Comes with a built-in artefact containers.

Suit for mercenaries who foraged in the anomalous zones. Protection systems with a closed cycle, built-in suppression action anomalous fields. It provides good protection from bullet and shrapnel hit, but not enough for large-scale hostilities. Fully upgradeable and boasting two built-in artefact containers.

An armour made by either Monolithians or an unknown manufacturer. It includes a flak vest of unknown origin and also features unique modifications creating a slight resistance to radiation. The anomaly protection system has been upgraded to match the SEVA bodysuit. The suit has two artefact containers.

An armour made by either Monolithians or an unknown manufacturer. It includes a flak vest of unknown origin and also features unique modifications creating a slight resistance to radiation. The suit has two artefact containers.

An armour made by either Monolithians or an unknown manufacturer. It includes a flak vest of unknown origin and also features unique modifications creating a slight resistance to radiation. System has been upgraded to match the military exoskeleton bodysuit. The suit has two artefact containers.

The jacket consists of a black leather anorak with Kevlar patches sewn into it and blue tracksuit pants tucked into white running shoes and a beige hoodie worn underneath. Typically, it's also worn with a backpack made of hemp with extra straps across the chest.

A regular black leather trench coat. Has no special purpose other than to keep the wearer warm at night or protect him from a blind dog bite. Although the trench coat is not particularly comfortable, it is often used by bandits in the Zone - either because it allows them to hide in the dark or simply due to its "cool" appearance.

Outfit of choice for the Mercenary faction, recently "liberated" by bandits. The bandit variation suffers from external damage providing less adequate protection across the board, but is not only less costly, but easier to get a hold of.

This is a modified type of standard Exoskeleton. Produced with the participation of partisans from the group "Bandits". Bandit Exoskeleton use lighter materials, what allowed to reduce the weight of the suit. Comes with a built-in artefact container.

This item comprises military PS5 series body armour with beryllium sputter modified for use in the Zone. Designed for assault operations in highly radioactive areas, it is ineffective in areas of high anomalous activity. The suit makes its way to stalkers through the military, who exchange it for loot. Does not come with an artefact container.

This modern military armoured suit is designed for assault operations in anomalous areas. Comprises a PSZ-12p heavy military armoured suit, built-in compensation suit, and an anomalous protection bodysuit. The armour provides excellent protection against bullet and fragmentation damage, without greatly reducing the wearer's mobility. Does not come with an artefact container.

The Military members decided using heavier materials to improve bullet resistance over others, this version of the exoskeleton though heavy makes one feel like a tank. The only downfall is the weak anomaly protection provided with the armour is very lacking and even the most basic of anomalies can take down this tank. Does not come with an artefact container.

An aluminium/titanium helmet with a cloth exterior that comes with pockets for additional steel armour pieces and an armour face mask. Sphere M12 is normally used as part of a combination that includes PSZ series Spetsnaz body armour. Quite popular in the Zone thanks to its respirator and built-in first generation night vision device, as well as providing the maximum head protection possible. Comes with electronics slots.

A desperately outdated steel army helmet without any additions. Provides no protection against anomalies or radiation, but can deflect bullets. This helmet was never particularly popular in the Zone, except for use in brief armed conflicts between factions.

A light helmet with an airtight visor intended for protection from anomalies. Judging by the design, the helmet is made by the same Defence Research Institutes as the SEVA bodysuit. Its intended use may very well be in combination with military suits for operations in highly anomalous areas.

A regular plastic and rubber gas mask, used for filtering air for radioactive particles and poisonous substances. Widely used by rookies and veterans of all factions due to its universal functionality. Does not provide any physical protection.

A Western model of a tactical helmet that lacks camouflage. It is not known how it made its way into the Zone. The helmet is designed to provide a squad leader with strategic superiority over the enemy via its many scanners and satellite communications devices, which have not been installed in this particular helmet. Comes with multi-layered Kevlar protection and armoured elements to protect electronic components. Includes a respirator and a first generation night vision device.

The M40 was the result of a program in the 1980s to develop a successor to the M17-series protective masks. The M40 was to be a return to conventional gas mask design with an external side-mounted filter canister, rather than the internal cheek filters of the M17, which were awkward to change, especially in a contaminated environment. The M40 is favoured amongst westerners such as the Mercenaries, lacking strong protection vs. anomalies the M40 provide moderate bullet protection.
This exoskeleton provides outstanding protection against bullet and fragmentation damage at the cost of mobility. Vulnerable to armour-piercing rounds.

A military armoured suit made for assault operations. Provides outstanding protection against full metal jacket rounds and fragmentation damage without reducing the wearer's mobility. Vulnerable to armour-piercing rounds.

This bodysuit, intended for conducting research in the Zone, combines a closed-cycle respiratory module and an external isolation coating, resulting in excellent protection from anomalies. Due to poor protection from physical impact, the suit is not a good defence against bullet and fragmentation damage. Comes with a built-in artefact transportation container.
